title: CIOs Nominate Their Favorite Reads of 2022; The reading list ranged from books on data and machine-learning to ones on women in leadership, inspiring a team and geopolitics
text:
But it wasn't all about managing data and people. Among the books tech leaders nominated were an autobiographical book on humanizing technology; one on Pfizer's dash to develop a Covid vaccine; another on how thought processes work; climate change; decompressing and the centrality of sleep; even a book on palmistry (who doesn't want to know the future?).

So read on. Edited highlights below.

Chris Bedi, chief digital information officer, ServiceNow Inc.

The Mathematical Corporation: Where Machine Intelligence and Human Ingenuity Achieve the Impossible Josh Sullivan and Angela Zutavern (2017) "This is a great read for CIOs looking to learn more about making AI or machine learning a reality in the enterprise."

Bill Braun, chief information officer, Chevron Corp. Leadership: Six Studies in World Strategy Henry Kissinger (2022)

"It brings powerful lessons from the seemingly insurmountable challenges humankind has faced in recent history. These examples are super inspiring and I hope will help grow the leadership of today's generation and the future generation."

Monica Caldas, deputy chief information officer, Liberty Mutual Insurance Think Again: The Power of Knowing What You Don't Know Adam Grant (2021)

"It highlights the need to continuously take in new information and iterate your thinking."

Brett Craig, chief information officer, Target Corp. How to Avoid a Climate Disaster: The Solutions We Have and the Breakthroughs We Need Bill Gates (2021)

"As a CIO, I appreciated Gates's point of view on technologyâ€”it's critical to maintaining the health of our communities and our planet, but can't solve everything." Jae Evans, chief information officer, Oracle Corp. Burnout: The Secret of Unlocking the Stress Cycle Emily Nagoski and Amelia Nagoski (2019) "I found the prescriptive tips and recommended steps to reduce stress in your home and work life useful for me personally."

Kathryn Guarini, chief information officer, IBM Corp. When Women Lead: What They Achieve, Why They Succeed, and How We Can Learn from Them Julia Boorstin (2022) "What resonated with me in this book are the good and inspiring stories of women who have succeeded in leadership roles."

Ron Guerrier, chief information officer, HP Inc. The Inspirational Leader: Inspire Your Team To Believe In The Impossible Gifford Thomas (2019)

"This book provided valuable insights on how to inspire teams and those we are privileged to serve."

Ravi Malik, chief information officer, Box Inc. The Ideal Team Player: How to Recognize and Cultivate The Three Essential Virtues Patrick Lencioni (2016)

"Given the 'Great Resignation' and general reshuffling of technical talent across all industries, it gave me insight into an easily usable framework for both recruiting and retaining talent."

Sharon Mandell, chief information officer, Juniper Networks Inc. The Economics of Data, Analytics, and Digital Transformation: The Theorems, Laws, and Empowerments to Guide your Organization's Digital Transformation Bill Schmarzo (2020)

"I believe good data will be the rocket fuel of all innovation."

Brad Peterson, chief technology and chief information officer, Nasdaq Inc. Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams Matthew Walker (2017)

"This book illuminates the science and the importance of our sleep. And how this simple act of quality resting can be the most effective way of living a healthier, smarter and more productive life."

Fletcher Previn, chief information officer, Cisco Systems Inc. Spies, Lies, and Algorithms: The History and Future of American Intelligence Amy Zegart (2022) "This book explores the impact modern technology and unprecedented access to information is having on our society, in shaping opinions and on how intelligence agencies operate in this new world."

Hasmukh Ranjan, chief information officer, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. The Art and Science of Hand Reading: Classical Methods for Self-Discovery through Palmistry Ellen Goldberg and Dorian Bergen (2016)

"People are more curious to know the future especially in trying times!"

Ramon Richards, chief information officer, Fannie Mae Investments Unlimited: A Novel About DevOps, Security, Audit Compliance, and Thriving in the Digital Age Helen Beal, Bill Bensing, Jason Cox, Michael Edenzon and John Willis (2022)

"The storytelling in the book outlines an approach to operating efficiently with DevOps, audit, compliance and security to deliver high-quality software."

John Roese, chief technology officer, Dell Technologies Risk: A User's Guide General Stanley McChrystal and Anna Butrico (2021)

"Understanding how to think through risk is such an important skill, or else you freeze and don't end up making any decisions, which is a really bad idea."

Fahim Siddiqui, chief information officer, Home Depot Inc. Noise: A Flaw in Human Judgment Daniel Kahneman, Olivier Sibony, and Cass Sunstein (2021) "This book helped me to become more aware and more critical of my own decision-making process and also of how I evaluate information to help get to the best possible decisions. When we are the most introspective, we are possibly at our most creative." Scott Spradley, chief technology and automation officer, Tyson Foods Inc. Moonshot: Inside Pfizer's Nine-Month Race to Make the Impossible Possible Albert Bourla (2022) "It was interesting to hear how their board was completely committed to supporting whatever it took."

Mark Spykerman, chief information officer, AmerisourceBergen Corp. Subtract: The Untapped Science of Less Leidy Klotz (2021)

"It's human nature to try solving problems by adding a step or an extra feature, but that may not always be the right answer, and this is particularly true when working with technology."

Ashok Srivastava, chief data officer, Intuit Inc. Build: An Unorthodox Guide to Making Things Worth Making Tony Fadell (2022) "Written by the inventor of the iPod, iPhone and Nest thermostats, this book gives insight into some of the most transformational customer-driven innovations in our lifetime."

Bonnie Titone, chief information officer, Duke Energy Corp. New to Big: How Companies Can Create Like Entrepreneurs, Invest Like VCs, and Install a Permanent Operating System for Growth David Kidder and Christina Wallace (2019) "It's all about how to create a culture of thinking like an entrepreneur, thinking like an innovator, and how to build those practices into even the most traditional of companies."

Alessandro Ventura, chief information officer and vice president of analytics and business services, Unilever North America How the Future Works: Leading Flexible Teams To Do The Best Work of Their Lives Brian Elliott, Sheela Subramanian and Helen Kupp (2022)

"Brian's book changed the way I think about what we need in the hybrid workforce."

Jeff Wong, chief innovation officer, EY Girl Decoded: A Scientist's Quest to Reclaim Our Humanity by Bringing Emotional Intelligence to Technology Rana el Kaliouby (2020)

"Rana has an amazing story that not only inspires me and my work in the innovation sector, but has inspired countless people in the AI and tech space."
